newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Dutch September consumer prices rise 2.0 pct yr/yr.
newsitem.headline: Dutch September consumer prices rise 2.0 pct yr/yr.

text.p: The Dutch consumer price index (CPI) rose a provisional 0.9 percent in September from August, giving a 2.0 percent year-on-year rise, the Central Bureau of Statistics (CBS) said.
DUTCH CONSUMER PRICE INFLATION Sept 96 Aug 96 Sept 95

NOTES - Economists had expected the September CPI to rise between 1.9 and 2.1 percent year-on-year with a consensus forecast of 2.0 percent. The consensus forecast for the month-on-month increase in the CPI was 0.9 percent.

The CBS said a 14.2 percent rise in prices of clothing and shoes was one of the main reasons for the increase in the CPI between August and September. It said this was a normal seasonal effect caused by the end of retailers' summer sales and the introduction of winter clothing collections.
Prices of fresh fruit and vegetables rose 3.3 percent from August to September, contributing to a 0.5 percent average rise for the entire food and drink component of the CPI.
University and college tuition fees were raised by 7.5 pct in September compared with a 2.3 percent rise in September 1995.
